Legal_Issue: Exclusion from refugee status under Article 1E of the Refugee Convention
Governing_Law: Article 1E of the United Nations Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Ability to return to and receive protection from Germany
Application_Factor: No risk of deportation from Germany
Decision_Outcome: Dismissal of refugee claim
No certification of questions
Authority: United Nations Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees

Crimes.Violation_Type: Exclusion from Convention refugee status under Article 1(E)
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Article 1(E) of the UN Refugee Convention
Crimes.Application_Facts: Vifansi fled U.S. criminal charges and lost re-entry rights; Board assumed 'official status' without proper assessment
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Non-compliant due to loss of asylum protection and re-entry rights in the U.S.
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Board misapprehended facts regarding applicant's U.S. status
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Judicial review on grounds of legal error and factual misinterpretation
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Assessment of U.S. 'official status' affecting Canadian refugee determination
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Evidence that Vifansi lost asylum protection and had no re-entry rights in the U.S.
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Board failed to assess actual rights under Article 1(E)
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not directly challenged; decision based on legal misinterpretation
Crimes.Outcome: Remanded for redetermination by a different panel
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Error in law due to incorrect assumption of 'official status'

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Refugee status exclusion based on prior conduct and status
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Application of Article 1(E) exclusion due to alleged 'official status' in the U.S.
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Board ignored evidence that applicant lost asylum protection and re-entry rights
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to establish refugee status; Board must properly assess exclusion grounds
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Applicant’s flight from U.S. criminal charges assessed in context of refugee claim
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Article 1(E) excludes persons with rights/obligations akin to nationality
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Misinterpretation of facts and law by the Board
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Loss of asylum protection and lack of re-entry rights in the U.S.
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Refugee determination process under Canadian immigration law
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Not applicable – administrative decision under judicial review
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Documentary and testimonial evidence on U.S. immigration status

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Refugee claim involving flight from prosecution
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether fleeing prosecution affects eligibility for refugee status under Article 1(E)
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Board failed to assess actual rights in the U.S.; relied on incorrect assumptions
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: Applicant must demonstrate refugee status; exclusion must be properly justified
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Flight to Canada after facing U.S. charges evaluated in refugee context
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Article 1(E) exclusion applies only if individual has rights akin to nationality
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Legal error and misapprehension of facts
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Applicant’s loss of asylum protection and inability to re-enter the U.S.
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Canadian refugee determination system under IRPA
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Not applicable – challenge to administrative decision
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Testimonial and documentary evidence on immigration status
Crimes.Outcome: Case remanded to a different panel

Legal_Issue: Applicability of Article 1E of the United Nations Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees
Governing_Law: United Nations Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees, Article 1E
Evidence_Type: Evidence of right to return to France
Basis_of_Claim: Claim for refugee status in Canada
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Holding rights and obligations akin to nationality in France
Assessment_Standard: Whether applicants were excluded under Article 1E based on residency rights in France
Application_Factor: Possession of French residency rights despite expired documents
Decision_Outcome: Excluded from Convention refugee status

Violation_Type: Exclusion from refugee status under international convention
Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), Refugee Convention
Application_Facts: Victor Kroon, a Russian citizen residing in Estonia since 1973, claimed persecution in Estonia despite having rights and obligations similar to Estonian nationals.
Claimant_Status: Russian citizen with long-term residency in Estonia
Residency_Compliance: Kroon had established residency in Estonia with rights akin to nationality
Procedural_Issue: Tribunal applied Article 1E correctly; no procedural error found on judicial review
Jurisdictional_Issue: Canadian immigration authorities' jurisdiction to assess refugee claim despite claimant's effective nationality-like status abroad
Evidence_Used: Tribunal's findings on Kroon's rights in Estonia, duration of residence, and integration
Credibility_Assessment: Not challenged; focus was on legal exclusion under Article 1E rather than credibility
Decision_Outcome: Application for refugee status dismissed
Relief_Sought: Recognition as a Convention refugee in Canada
Legal_Standard_Applied: Article 1E of the Refugee Convention – exclusion where rights and obligations of nationality exist
Decision_Rationale: Kroon enjoys rights and obligations in Estonia akin to those of an Estonian national, thus he is excluded from Convention refugee status under Article 1E
Authority_Responsible: Immigration and Refugee Board (IRB), Federal Court of Canada

Legal_Provision_Violated: Article 1E of the Convention on the Status of Refugees
Governing_Law: Convention on the Status of Refugees
Application_Facts: Kanesharan, a Sri Lankan Tamil, fled to the UK and later Canada; Board considered a statutory declaration regarding his rights in the UK
Residency_Compliance: Not applicable – claimant no longer resident in the UK
Misrepresentation_Element: Statutory declaration used tentative language about deportation and eligibility
Procedural_Issue: Board failed to properly assess whether rights were equivalent to nationality
Jurisdictional_Issue: Application of Article 1E in Canadian refugee determination process
Evidence_Used: Statutory declaration suggesting rights akin to UK nationals
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Use of speculative and non-conclusive language in the statutory declaration
Decision_Outcome: Board excluded Kanesharan from refugee status under Article 1E
Outcome: Federal Court found error, set aside decision
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of the Board’s decision
Remedy_Sought: Redetermination of refugee status by the Board
Legal_Standard_Applied: Interpretation of Article 1E – rights and obligations substantially similar to nationality
Decision_Rationale: Board erred in relying on insufficient evidence to conclude that Kanesharan had rights akin to nationality in the UK

Governing_Law: Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees
Canadian jurisprudence on refugee status determination
Application_Facts: Choovak had permanent resident status in Germany which expired; she claimed inability to return to Iran and fear of persecution in Germany
Residency_Compliance: Failed to maintain valid German residency; status allowed renewal but was not renewed
Procedural_Issue: CRDD failed to properly analyze claim against Germany
Insufficient consideration of renewability of German status
Jurisdictional_Issue: Focus on Iran despite primary claim rooted in conditions in Germany
Evidence_Used: Evidence of expired German permanent residency
Evidence of ability to renew residency in Germany
Minimal evidence regarding conditions in Iran
Evidentiary_Deficiency: CRDD ignored evidence that Choovak could renew German residency
Lack of analysis on enjoyment of basic rights in Germany
Decision_Outcome: CRDD granted refugee status based on fear of persecution in Iran
Outcome: Federal Court quashed the CRDD decision
Legal_Standard_Applied: Application of Article 1E of the Refugee Convention
Decision_Rationale: CRDD erred by not recognizing that Choovak retained rights akin to nationality in Germany through renewable residency, and improperly shifted focus to Iran when her claim centered on Germany

Legal_Issue: Does Article 1E of the Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees exclude Nepete from obtaining Convention refugee status in Canada?
Governing_Law: Article 1E of the Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees
Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed; Nepete excluded from Convention refugee status
Evidence_Type: Permanent resident status in the Czech Republic
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Enjoyment of rights and obligations similar to nationals of the country of residence
Legal_Standard: Convention refugee status under Article 1E exclusion
Application_Factor: Permanent residency in a third country
Decision_Outcome: Excluded from refugee status under Article 1E

Outcome: Judicial review allowed, decision set aside for redetermination
Evidence_Type: Medical status (HIV positive), anti-discrimination laws, medication availability, societal stigma, family support
Basis_of_Claim: Fear of persecution based on sexual orientation and HIV status
Key_Factor_in_Determination: HIV-related stigma, employment restrictions, lack of family support
Application_Error: Failure to consider HIV status in IFA analysis
Evidence_Ignored: Systemic barriers related to HIV status including stigma and lack of support
Legal_Standard: Two-pronged IFA test: (1) no serious possibility of persecution, (2) reasonable to seek refuge
Decision_Outcome: Decision set aside, case referred for redetermination

Crimes.Crime_Name: Use of a fraudulent exit visa

Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Credible fear of persecution, procedural fairness
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Delay in claiming refugee status and return to Cuba undermined credibility of fear of persecution

Legal_Issue: Can the Defendant rely on sections 366 and 368 of the Criminal Code as part of their defence in a civil patent infringement case?
Governing_Law: Sections 366 and 368 of the Criminal Code
Outcome: The portions of paragraph 22 referring to sections 366 and 368 of the Criminal Code are struck out due to futility and prejudice.
Basis_of_Claim: Alleged false representations or forgery related to a patent application
Key_Factor_in_Determination: No direct connection between the alleged conduct and the Criminal Code provisions; lack of jurisdiction in civil court over criminal matters
Proceeding_Type: Civil patent infringement case with motion to strike
Application_Error: Attempting to invoke criminal statutes in a civil context without statutory authority or direct relevance
Legal_Standard: Federal Court lacks jurisdiction over criminal prosecutions unless explicitly authorized
Application_Factor: Relevance of criminal law provisions to civil defence
Decision_Outcome: Motion partially granted: references to Criminal Code struck out, s. 76 Patent Act may remain
Document_Fraud: Allegation of forged document related to patent application

Legal_Issue: Can the Defendant rely on penal provisions of the Patent Act and Criminal Code as part of their defence in a civil patent infringement case?
Outcome: Portion of paragraph 22 referring to the Criminal Code is struck out as scandalous and prejudicial.
Basis_of_Claim: Defendant alleged Plaintiffs engaged in misconduct under penal statutes including forgery
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of direct connection between penal allegations and civil harm; no general criminal jurisdiction in Federal Court
Proceeding_Type: Civil patent infringement with motion to strike
Application_Error: Use of criminal law provisions where no cause of action or defence arises from them
Legal_Standard: Federal Court cannot entertain criminal charges absent statutory grant
Application_Factor: Applicability of penal provisions in civil litigation
Decision_Outcome: References to Criminal Code struck out; amendment allowed regarding s. 76 of Patent Act
Document_Fraud: Allegation of forged documents in patent context

Legal_Issue: Can the Defendant use s. 76 of the Patent Act and ss. 366 and 368 of the Criminal Code as a defense or counterclaim in a civil patent infringement case?
Governing_Law: Sections 366 and 368 of the Criminal Code
Procedural_Stage: Motion to strike parts of Defence and Counterclaim
Decision_Outcome: References to Criminal Code removed; liberty granted to amend concerning s. 76 of Patent Act
Legal_Rule: s. 76 prohibits false representations about patent status; ss. 366–368 are criminal forgery provisions not applicable in civil defences
Grounds_for_Claim: Plaintiffs allegedly made false representations about a patent application
Outcome_on_Merits: No valid defence based on Criminal Code; s. 76 may have arguable relevance
Legal_Framework: Civil patent law framework with limited applicability of penal provisions
Defendant_Response: Invoked s. 76 Patent Act and Criminal Code provisions as part of defence
Remedy_Requested: Striking out of irrelevant and prejudicial allegations
Outcome: Partial success for Plaintiffs: Criminal Code references struck, s. 76 issue preserved subject to amendment

Crimes.Evidence_Type: Testimonial evidence, lack of corroborating documentation
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Sections 96, 97, and subsection 72(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Fear of persecution by FARC in Colombia due to extortion and violence
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of credibility and adequacy of state protection in Colombia
Crimes.Decision_Maker: Refugee Protection Division (RPD), reviewed by Federal Court
Crimes.Application_Error: Inconsistent testimony affecting credibility
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Well-founded fear of persecution or risk to life upon return
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: None explicitly stated; inconsistencies undermined overall credibility
Crimes.Application_Factor: Presumption of state protection not rebutted
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Misrepresentation in supporting claims for refugee status

Crimes.Victim_Status: Individual claiming victimization by armed group
Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Threats and demands by an illegal armed organization
Crimes.Prior_Criminality: Not applicable to applicant; attributed to FARC
Crimes.Criminality_Severity: High (alleged assault and threats by insurgent group)
Crimes.Risk_Assessment: Assessed as not credible due to inconsistencies
Crimes.Risk_Type: Personal safety risk from non-state actor
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Targeted threat based on alleged extortion
Crimes.Targeted_Victimization: Yes, based on alleged refusal to fully comply with extortion demand
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Self-reported testimony without corroboration
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Found lacking due to implausible details
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Doubted due to inconsistencies in narrative
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Sections 96 and 97 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act

Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Pattern of threats and extortion preceding attempted abduction
Crimes.Mitigating_Factors: Availability of state protection mechanisms in Colombia
Crimes.Prior_Criminality: Attributed to FARC as ongoing armed insurgency
Crimes.Criminality_Severity: High (threat of unlawful detention and harm)
Crimes.Risk_Assessment: Deemed not well-founded due to credibility issues
Crimes.Risk_Type: Risk of arbitrary deprivation of liberty
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Targeted threat linked to extortion campaign
Crimes.Targeted_Victimization: Yes, based on prior interactions and payments
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Oral testimony with inconsistencies
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Found not credible by RPD
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Sections 96 and 97 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act

Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Use of threats and fear of violence to extract payments
Crimes.Mitigating_Factors: Existence of state institutions capable of providing protection
Crimes.Prior_Criminality: Pattern of criminal behavior by FARC documented
Crimes.Criminality_Severity: High (coercion backed by threat of violence)
Crimes.Risk_Assessment: Present but deemed manageable through state protection
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Ongoing coercive demands from non-state armed group
Crimes.Targeted_Victimization: Yes, repeated demands directed at applicant
Crimes.Evidence_Sufficiency: Partially supported by general country conditions, but individual claim lacked credibility
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Testimonial evidence, country condition reports
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Undermined by inconsistencies in testimony
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Sections 96 and 97 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act

Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant is an elderly woman who overstayed her visa and sought permanent residency on humanitarian and compassionate grounds due to her daughter's disability and inability to return to Guatemala.
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Request for humanitarian and compassionate consideration under subsection 25(1)
Evidence_Used: Potential reliance on Canadian social services
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient evidence provided regarding daughter's condition and lack of support from other relatives
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Permanent resident status on humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Humanitarian and compassionate considerations under subsection 25(1)
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Burden on Canadian services outweighed compassionate considerations; insufficient evidence of hardship

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to apply for permanent residence from outside Canada as required by the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Refusal of humanitarian and compassionate exemption
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of officer's refusal under subsection 25(1)
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Subsection 25(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Insufficient evidence supporting hardship claim and potential burden on social services
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to meet procedural requirement to apply from outside Canada
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Refusal of exemption request under subsection 25(1)

Crimes.Crime_Name: False or Misleading Information for Passport Application
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of Passport Canada's decision to revoke passport and impose refusal period
Crimes.Governing_Law: Canadian Passport Order, SI/81-86, sections 9, 10, and 10.2
Crimes.Outcome: Judicial review dismissed; four-year refusal period upheld
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant admitted submitting misleading information
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Admission of false statements, application records
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Submission of false information to obtain passport for brother
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Integrity of passport system prioritized over humanitarian claims
Crimes.Application_Error: Providing false identity information (brother's photo and loss claim)
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness standard applied by Federal Court
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Humanitarian circumstances related to brother fleeing persecution
Crimes.Legal_Standard: No requirement to prove intent to defraud
Crimes.Application_Factor: Use of misleading information in passport application
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Revocation and four-year refusal period imposed

Crimes.Crime_Name: Permitting Another to Use a Passport
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of Passport Canada's decision to revoke passport and impose refusal period
Crimes.Outcome: Judicial review dismissed; four-year refusal period upheld
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant admitted providing false information and allowing brother to use passport
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Admission of fraudulent use, application and investigation records
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Provisions on fraudulent acquisition or use of passport
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Allowing another person to use passport obtained through false information
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Protection of passport integrity outweighs personal circumstances
Crimes.Application_Error: Submitting false information enabling unauthorized use
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness standard applied by Federal Court
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Humanitarian motives for assisting brother
Crimes.Legal_Standard: No proof of intent to defraud required
Crimes.Application_Factor: Facilitation of illegal entry through passport misuse
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Revocation and four-year refusal period imposed

Crimes.Crime_Name: Obtaining a Passport by Means of False or Misleading Information
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of Passport Canada's decision to revoke passport and impose four-year refusal period
Crimes.Outcome: Federal Court dismissed judicial review; decision upheld
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant admitted using brother's photo and false loss statement
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Admission, photographic evidence, application documents
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Provisions allowing revocation for false information without intent to defraud
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Obtaining passport under false pretenses to assist brother fleeing persecution
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Preservation of passport program integrity
Crimes.Application_Error: Submitting false photo and misrepresenting loss of passport
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Humanitarian purpose behind the fraud
Crimes.Legal_Standard: No requirement to prove fraudulent intent
Crimes.Application_Factor: Use of false documentation to obtain travel document
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Passport revoked, four-year ban imposed (reduced from five years due to cooperation)

Crimes.Crime_Name: Inadmissibility under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Violation_Type: Membership in organization involved in subversion by force
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant admitted membership in CLM, which was linked to an attack in Namibia; evidence reasonably supports CLM's involvement in subversion.
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: No direct misrepresentation found, but inconsistencies in statements raised concerns
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Judicial review conducted based on reasonableness and correctness standards
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Admission of CLM membership, links between CLM and the 1999 attack in Namibia, leadership connection to Mr. Muyongo
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Some inconsistencies in applicant's statements, but not sufficient to undermine decision
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Partially credible with noted inconsistencies
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Mere membership in an organization engaged in subversion by force is sufficient for inadmissibility under s. 34(1)(f)

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Alleged error in finding inadmissibility despite lack of direct involvement
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether ID erred in finding Tjiueza inadmissible under s. 34(1)(f) due to inconsistencies and denial of violent involvement
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Concerns due to discrepancies in statements about CLM/CLA identity and activities
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Testimonial evidence, documentary links between CLM and 1999 attack
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Membership in organization deemed to engage in subversion by force
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Admission of CLM membership and conflation of CLM with CLA responsible for attack
Crimes.Application_Error: None found – ID’s interpretation upheld
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: None identified as unreasonable
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Reasonableness of factual findings and legal interpretation
Crimes.Application_Factor: Lack of application for relief under s. 34(2)

Crimes.Crime_Name: Membership in organization engaging in subversion by force of a government
Crimes.Violation_Type: Membership in organization involved in subversion by force
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant admitted membership in CLM; ID found reasonable grounds to link CLM to 1999 attack under Mr. Muyongo’s leadership
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Inconsistencies in statements led to credibility concerns
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Judicial review assessing factual and legal basis of ID decision
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Membership admission, organizational links to violent attack, leadership structure
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Minor inconsistencies, but overall evidence deemed sufficient
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Partially credible – discrepancies noted but did not invalidate conclusion
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Mere membership suffices for inadmissibility if organization engaged in subversion by force

Crime_Name: Work Permit Refusal under Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Legal_Issue: Procedural fairness and reasonableness of visa officer's decision
Credibility_Assessment: Applicant lacked sufficient ties to India to ensure departure
Evidence_Type: Documents showing ties to India, economic prospects in India
Legal_Provision: Section related to work permit issuance and procedural fairness
Basis_of_Claim: Insufficient demonstration of intent to return to home country
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of strong residential, economic, or familial ties to India
Evidence_Ignored: No explicit mention of ignoring evidence; considered available documents
Application_Factor: Economic incentives to remain in Canada, limited prospects in India
Decision_Outcome: Work permit refused

Legal_Issue: Breach of natural justice, adequacy of reasons, and reasonableness
Credibility_Assessment: Applicant had limited prospects and weak ties to India
Evidence_Type: Submitted documents on ties to India, employment prospects
Legal_Provision: Provisions governing work permit applications and officer discretion
Basis_of_Claim: Concerns about applicant’s intent to return to India after work period
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Economic incentives to stay in Canada, lack of strong foreign ties
Evidence_Ignored: Not required to explicitly address every piece of evidence
Application_Factor: Residential ties, job prospects abroad, incentive to comply with temporary status
Decision_Outcome: Work permit refused

Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of IRB's assessment of state protection in Mexico
Outcome: Judicial review granted, decision quashed, case remanded for redetermination
Credibility_Assessment: Applicants' evidence of threats and corruption deemed credible
Evidence_Type: Threats from political figure, reports to authorities, systemic police corruption
Legal_Provision: Section 97(1) of IRPA - Basis for refugee protection
Basis_of_Claim: Fear of persecution with inadequate state protection
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Widespread corruption and inefficacy of Mexican police forces
Application_Error: Failure to adequately consider evidence of lack of state protection
Evidence_Ignored: Extent of corruption and risks post-complaint in Mexico
Legal_Standard: Presumption of state ability rebutted by credible evidence
Application_Factor: Democracy with systemic corruption affecting protection
Decision_Outcome: Unreasonable dismissal of claim

Crimes.Application_Factor: State protection availability in Nigeria considered adequate

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the Board's credibility determination was reasonably justified
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Board failed to provide clear and specific reasons for doubting credibility on material issues
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Travel documents, applicant testimony on domestic abuse

Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Focus on peripheral issues (travel documents) over core claim (abuse)
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to identify specific inconsistencies in core claim
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Core evidence related to domestic abuse
Crimes.Application_Factor: Use of false travel documents not determinative of overall credibility
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Rejection of refugee claim based on credibility

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether use of false travel documents justified negative credibility finding

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether speculation about immigration status undermined credibility unreasonably

Crimes.Application_Factor: Irrelevant assumptions about lawful status in third countries
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Refugee claim rejected due to credibility concerns

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Credibility, delay, state protection, procedural fairness
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Negative credibility findings due to multiple PIF amendments and inconsistencies
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence supporting state protection, incomplete transcript supplemented by notes

Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Patent unreasonableness for credibility, reasonableness for state protection, correctness for procedural fairness
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: None identified – court found record sufficient despite incomplete transcript
Crimes.Application_Factor: Delay in leaving country and applying for refugee status
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Misrepresentation in border or immigration documents

Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: IRPA section on temporary resident overstay
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant remained in Canada after visa expiration and later claimed refugee status
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Former temporary resident turned refugee claimant
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Discrepancies in PIF narratives affecting credibility
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Incomplete hearing transcript reviewed for procedural fairness
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court jurisdiction over IRB decisions
Crimes.Evidence_Used: PIF statements, documentary evidence on country conditions
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of objective evidence supporting fear of persecution
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Negatively assessed due to inconsistent narratives
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Refugee claim rejected; judicial review dismissed
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Recognition as Convention refugee or person in need of protection
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Allowance of refugee claim or remittal for new hearing
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: No subjective or objective basis for fear; state protection available

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Refugee status determination with allegations of non-disclosure
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Credibility, disclosure obligations, procedural fairness
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Judicial review of refugee claim refusal
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Substantial PIF amendments considered; documentary evidence supported state protection
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Application dismissed – no patent unreasonableness or breach of natural justice
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to establish well-founded fear of persecution
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Credibility assessed for patent unreasonableness; natural justice requires 'serious possibility' of prejudice
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Claim dismissed due to lack of credible evidence
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: PIF versions, country condition reports, hearing notes
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Board maintained decision based on credibility and available protections
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Narrative statements, official documents, procedural records
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Certification of question or remittal of claim
Crimes.Legal_Provision: IRPA provisions on refugee eligibility and misrepresentation

Crimes.Application_Facts: Mr. Singh did not disclose his daughter during immigration; DNA tests later confirmed paternity
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Non-compliant due to failure to disclose dependent family member
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Omission of a material fact (biological child) that could induce error in immigration decision-making
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Judicial review of Immigration Appeal Division's decision
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal court jurisdiction over immigration inadmissibility
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of disclosure at time of application despite potential knowledge
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Court rejected defense of ignorance; found duty of candour existed
Crimes.Outcome: Exclusion order set aside, case remanded
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Reconsideration on humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Materiality of omission under Section 40(1)(a) IRPA
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Failure to disclose biological child constituted material misrepresentation regardless of intent

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to disclose material facts under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether failure to disclose biological child amounts to misrepresentation under IRPA

Dispute_Type: Complaint of racial discrimination in a federal workplace
Legal_Issue: Whether the Canadian Human Rights Commission reasonably applied s. 41(1)(a) of the Canadian Human Rights Act
Evidence_Assessment: Applicant was given 90 days by the Chief of Defence Staff to file a harassment complaint but did not do so
Decision_Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed
Burden_of_Proof: On the applicant to demonstrate that internal procedures were not reasonably available or that failure to use them was justified
Credibility_Factor: Commission found the applicant's failure to use the internal process was attributable to the applicant
Legal_Rule: Under s. 41(1)(a), the Commission may decline a complaint if other grievance procedures have not been exhausted
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged racial discrimination by the employer
Outcome_on_Merits: Not reached; complaint dismissed on procedural grounds
Key_Evidence_Considered: Existence and availability of the internal harassment complaint process, timeline provided by Chief of Defence Staff
Legal_Framework: Administrative law, human rights law, statutory interpretation
Defendant_Response: The Commission declined the complaint due to unexhausted internal procedures
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence of policy and directives, procedural timelines
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review of the Commission’s decision to dismiss the complaint
Legal_Provision: s. 41(1)(a) of the Canadian Human Rights Act
Authority: Canadian Human Rights Commission, Federal Court

Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant remained in Canada beyond the authorized period of stay
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Jurisdiction of IRB over refugee claim
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Subjective fear dismissed due to delay
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Patent unreasonableness for credibility, reasonableness simpliciter for state protection
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Long delay in claiming refugee status; insufficient evidence of state protection failure

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to comply with removal order
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant remained in Canada after refugee claim rejection and issuance of removal order
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Assessment of ongoing risk despite removal order
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Board failed to consider available evidence on state protection
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Fear not adequately assessed; evidence ignored
Crimes.Outcome: Judicial review allowed; decision set aside
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Risk of gender-based persecution and state protection
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Patent unreasonableness for credibility, reasonableness for state protection
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Board erred in dismissing fear and underestimating state protection gaps in Jamaica

Crimes.Crime_Name: Domestic abuse (non-specific charges without more details, potential charges could include Assault, Criminal Harassment, Threatening Death under the Criminal Code of Canada)
Crimes.Mitigating_Factors: Not applicable in context of victimization
Crimes.Prior_Criminality: Perpetrator had history of abusive behavior
Crimes.Criminality_Severity: High – credible threats and physical harm
Crimes.Risk_Assessment: Ongoing risk upon return to country of origin
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Non-state actor violence with inadequate state protection
Crimes.Targeted_Victimization: Yes – based on gender and relationship
Evidence_Type: Expert reports on domestic violence in Jamaica
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Fear was subjectively genuine and objectively reasonable
Crimes.Sentencing_Issue: Not applicable – crime occurred abroad and not prosecuted in Canada
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Criminal Code of Canada (potential charges: Assault, Criminal Harassment, Threatening Death)

Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), Section 97(1)
Application_Facts: Applicants claimed refugee status due to persecution by Jamaat-e-Islami in Bangladesh
Residency_Compliance: Compliant with procedural timelines for appeal
Misrepresentation_Element: Adverse credibility findings on key claims including Telephone Threats and Family Threat
Procedural_Issue: RAD partially overturned RPD's credibility findings but upheld overall decision
Evidence_Used: Police corruption evidence, statements on threats from Jamaat-e-Islami
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient corroboration for threat claims, inconsistencies in testimony
Credibility_Assessment: Negative credibility assessment on multiple grounds; Non-Reporting finding overturned due to police corruption
Decision_Outcome: RPD dismissed appeal, RAD confirmed dismissal
Relief_Sought: Allowance of refugee appeal, reversal of RPD decision
Legal_Standard_Applied: Well-founded fear of persecution under IRPA
Decision_Rationale: Other negative credibility findings sufficient to support dismissal despite overturning one finding
Authority_Responsible: Refugee Appeal Division (RAD), Refugee Protection Division (RPD)

Application_Facts: The applicant faced abuse but did not pursue higher authorities or file complaints during a stay with her aunt. Evidence showed Mexico makes efforts to protect citizens, though local police were ineffective due to familial influence.
Claimant_Status: Applicant claiming refugee status in Canada
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review analyzed the RPD's decision under the reasonableness standard without substituting the court's opinion.
Evidence_Used: Evidence showed Mexico makes efforts to protect citizens, though local police were ineffective due to familial influence.
Decision_Outcome: The RPD's decision was reasonable and supported by evidence.
Outcome: The judicial review application was dismissed, upholding the RPD's original decision.
Legal_Standard_Applied: The claimant must prove no evidence supports the RPD's decision.
Decision_Rationale: The RPD concluded that Mexican authorities could provide protection to the applicant, and this conclusion was found to be reasonable based on available evidence.

Sentencing_Issue: Request for reduced nightly reporting requirements
Application of 'exceptional circumstances' test by Parole Board

Crime_Name: Humanitarian and Compassionate Grounds Application Rejection
Application_Facts: Lack of substantive evidence regarding hardship or unique circumstances; consideration of children's interests in Canada and Nigeria
Evidence_Used: Assessment of hardship, establishment, and risk factors
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of substantive evidence on hardship or unique circumstances
Decision_Outcome: H&C application rejected
Legal_Standard_Applied: Best interests of the children as a factor in H&C assessment
Decision_Rationale: No compelling reasons to grant an exception; children's interests considered but not outweighing other factors

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review of refugee claim decision
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether judicial review can be granted despite false testimony and omissions
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant found not credible due to inconsistencies and concealment
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Asylum based on alleged persecution
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Deliberate false testimony and failure to prove counsel incompetence
Crimes.Application_Error: False statements regarding departure date, route, and Swiss residence
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: None; new evidence deemed insufficient due to prior misconduct
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Demonstrable injustice due to counsel incompetence required
Crimes.Application_Factor: Blame on former counsel without proof
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: No relief granted, no new hearing ordered

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review involving credibility in refugee proceedings
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether perjury disqualifies applicant from discretionary relief
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: False testimony about travel and residence deemed material
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to show justification or error
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Perjury undermines claim and disqualifies from relief
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Allegation of poor legal advice excusing false statements
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Blamed former counsel for false statements
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Certification of question of general importance

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review of misrepresentation in asylum process
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether misrepresentation based on counsel’s advice invalidates claim
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant lacked credibility due to deliberate lies
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Refugee protection based on fabricated journey and history
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Intentional misrepresentation during sworn testimony
Crimes.Application_Error: False departure date, route, and omission of Switzerland stay
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: New evidence not considered due to prior fraud
Crimes.Application_Factor: Attempt to shift blame to counsel
Crimes.Document_Fraud: False statements in official refugee claim documents

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the officer erred in applying s. 25 of IRPA and adequately considering humanitarian and compassionate (H&C) factors, including the best interests of the children
Crimes.Outcome: Decision quashed, case remitted for re-determination
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Officer did not properly assess credibility in relation to H&C factors
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Affidavits, application records, evidence of family ties and children's circumstances
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Failure to disclose family members due to initial misrepresentation
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Best interests of the children and humanitarian and compassionate considerations
Crimes.Application_Error: Non-disclosure of family members in original application
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness of officer's interpretation and application of H&C factors
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Current family circumstances and impact on children
Crimes.Application_Factor: Initial non-disclosure leading to exclusion under s. 117(9)(d)
Crimes.Document_Fraud: No explicit document fraud; misrepresentation through omission

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to disclose family members in immigration application
Crimes.Application_Facts: Mr. Arif did not disclose wife and child during permanent residence application, citing advice from consultant
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Omission rather than affirmative false statement
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Officer failed to conduct meaningful H&C assessment
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Authority of immigration officer to apply s. 25 discretion
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Application forms, affidavits, evidence of family life and children’s best interests
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient consideration of H&C evidence by officer
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant claimed reliance on immigration consultant; not fully addressed by officer
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Decision found unreasonable, remitted for re-determination
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Inclusion of family members based on H&C grounds
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Re-determination by a different immigration officer
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Humanitarian and compassionate considerations under s. 25 IRPA
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Overemphasis on non-disclosure without proper balance of H&C factors

Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), sections related to refugee protection
Application_Facts: Applicant is Erika Angelina Zamora Huerta, claimed persecution due to domestic abuse by her common-law spouse, who is a Mexican police officer
Misrepresentation_Element: Alleged inconsistencies in testimony and identity documentation
Procedural_Issue: Board misapprehended facts, failed to consider explanations, applied flawed reasoning
Evidence_Used: Documentary evidence regarding conditions in Mexico
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Board ignored explanations and contradictory evidence
Credibility_Assessment: Board questioned applicant's identity and found inconsistencies; Court found assessment unreasonable
Decision_Outcome: Claim dismissed by the Refugee Protection Division
Remedy_Sought: Allowance of judicial review and remittal of the case
Legal_Standard_Applied: Well-founded fear of persecution on a Convention ground
Decision_Rationale: Board's conclusions on credibility, state protection, and IFA were based on misapprehended facts and lacked justification, transparency, and intelligibility
Authority_Responsible: Immigration and Refugee Board of Canada
